description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who leverage technical expertise claims to bypass security controls
description.context: When employees encounter complex technical problems beyond their knowledge, they often bypass normal security protocols and defer to anyone who sounds technically competent. Attackers exploit this by impersonating IT support, vendors, or technical consultants to gain system access, credentials, or sensitive information.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience successful social engineering through fake IT support, malicious software installation, credential harvesting, and data exfiltration. Historical incidents include Kevin Mitnick's extensive use of technical impersonation, RSA SecurID breach (2011), Target breach (2013), and Anthem breach (2015) where technical authority claims facilitated initial compromise and credential theft.
description.psychological_basis: Cognitive offloading - when individuals encounter technical complexity exceeding their expertise, they automatically transfer decision-making authority to perceived experts, bypassing normal verification protocols. This mechanism operates through epistemic dependence (reliance on others for specialized knowledge) combined with Dunning-Kruger effects where limited technical knowledge prevents evaluation of technical claims. Cognitive Load Theory explains why technical jargon overwhelms processing capacity, forcing reliance on source credibility rather than content evaluation.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Mandatory verification protocols for all technical support contacts exist and are consistently followed. Employees use callback verification to known numbers. Documented evidence of refused suspicious technical requests within last 6 months.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Basic verification procedures exist but aren't consistently followed. Some employees bypass verification under time pressure. Verification protocols only apply to certain types of technical requests but not others.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: No formal verification process for technical support contacts. Employees routinely comply with technical requests without verification. Recent incidents show successful social engineering through technical impersonation.

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Technical Support Verification Protocol
items.question: What is your mandatory verification procedure when someone claiming to be technical support contacts an employee requesting passwords, system access, or permission to install software?

options.label: Mandatory callback verification to known numbers required for all technical support contacts, with documented procedure accessible to all employees
Some verification steps exist but not consistently enforced or only apply to certain types of requests
No formal verification process - employees expected to comply with technical support requests

items.evidence_required: Written verification protocol, laminated reference cards at workstations, recent verification example

items.title: Callback Verification System Implementation
items.question: Do you have a system where employees can verify technical support claims by calling back to known, verified phone numbers?

options.label: Yes - Callback verification system exists, is regularly used, and recent examples show successful verification
System exists but rarely used or employees don't know how to access verified contact numbers
No callback verification system or verified contact database

items.evidence_required: Verified contact database, callback usage logs, specific recent example

items.title: External Technical Vendor Authentication
items.question: When external technical consultants or vendors request system access or sensitive information, what authentication process is required?

options.label: Multi-step authentication including verified vendor database, pre-authorized contact list, and documented approval workflow
Basic checks performed but no formal vendor database or standardized authentication process
Technical credentials accepted at face value without formal authentication process

items.evidence_required: Vendor authentication database, approval workflow documentation, recent vendor access example

items.title: Technical Impersonation Training and Simulation
items.question: What training and simulation exercises do employees receive on recognizing and responding to fake technical support scams?

options.label: Quarterly simulated technical support calls/emails with immediate feedback and declining success rates over time
Annual awareness training mentions technical impersonation but no hands-on simulation exercises
No specific training on technical authority verification or impersonation scenarios

items.evidence_required: Training curriculum with technical scenarios, simulation exercise results, trend data showing improvement

items.title: Centralized Technical Contact Logging
items.question: Is there a centralized system where all unsolicited technical support contacts must be immediately reported and logged?

options.label: Yes - Central logging required with evidence of consistent use and regular audit of logged contacts
Logging system exists but inconsistently used or no regular audit of entries
No centralized logging system for technical support contacts

items.evidence_required: Access to central logging system, recent log entries, audit schedule and results

items.title: Urgent Technical Request Policy
items.question: How does your organization balance speed with security verification when technical requests seem urgent or time-sensitive?

options.label: Verification remains required even for urgent requests with documented escalation paths that maintain security
Urgency sometimes justifies reduced verification with supervisor approval
Urgent technical requests processed immediately without verification delays

items.evidence_required: Written policy on urgent technical requests, recent urgent request examples with verification status

items.title: Technical Support Interaction Documentation
items.question: Are employees required to document all technical support interactions including verification steps taken?

options.label: Mandatory documentation with monthly audits showing consistent compliance and verification details
Documentation encouraged but not mandatory or not regularly audited
No documentation requirement for technical support interactions

items.evidence_required: Documentation standard policy, recent documented interactions, audit results

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk us through what happens when an employee receives an unsolicited technical support call or email. What are the exact verification steps they're supposed to follow?

scoring_guidance.green: Detailed multi-step procedure with callback verification, recent successful verification example, employees can recite the steps
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of verification need but vague process, inconsistent application, or no recent examples
scoring_guidance.red: No specific procedure, 'we trust IT when they call' response, or recent compliance without verification

followups.text: Tell us about the last time someone claiming to be IT support contacted your organization - what exactly happened and what verification was performed?
Where do employees find the verified contact numbers to call back? Can you show us this resource right now?

items.text: How often do your employees receive unsolicited technical support calls, emails, or visits from people claiming to be from IT vendors, consultants, or support services? What's your current monthly average?

scoring_guidance.green: Tracked metrics show frequency, examples of both legitimate and suspicious contacts identified, clear pattern recognition
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of frequency but no tracking, or inability to distinguish legitimate from suspicious patterns
scoring_guidance.red: No awareness of contact frequency, no tracking system, or assumption that all technical contacts are legitimate

followups.text: Of those contacts, how many turned out to be suspicious or were rejected after verification?
How do you track and analyze these technical support contacts?

items.text: What's your standard procedure when someone claiming to be technical support contacts an employee directly requesting passwords, system access, or permission to install software?

scoring_guidance.green: Never provide passwords, always callback verification, secondary approval required, documented examples of refused requests
scoring_guidance.yellow: General policy against sharing passwords but exceptions made, informal callback process, inconsistent enforcement
scoring_guidance.red: Employees provide credentials to apparent IT support, help desk resets passwords on request, 'helpful' culture overrides security

followups.text: Has an employee ever provided their password to someone claiming to be IT support? What happened?
What would happen if an employee insisted on verification before complying with an urgent technical request?

items.text: When legitimate external technical support needs access to your systems, what approval workflow do they go through? Who authorizes access and how quickly?

scoring_guidance.green: Multi-party approval required, documented vendor verification, mandatory delay period for non-emergency access, audit trail
scoring_guidance.yellow: Single approver required but no verification database, expedited approvals common, informal documentation
scoring_guidance.red: External technical experts granted access on request, no formal approval workflow, speed prioritized over verification

followups.text: Show us the most recent external technical vendor access request - who approved it and what verification was performed?
How do you distinguish between legitimate vendor technical support and potential impersonators?

items.text: Tell us about your employee training on recognizing fake technical support scams. When was the last training and what specific scenarios did it cover?

scoring_guidance.green: Quarterly simulation exercises with fake IT support calls/emails, scenario-based practice, metrics showing improved detection over time
scoring_guidance.yellow: Annual awareness training mentions topic but no hands-on practice, or outdated last training date
scoring_guidance.red: No specific training on technical impersonation, or training focuses on 'being helpful to IT' without verification emphasis

followups.text: What would a non-technical employee (admin staff, HR, executive assistant) do if someone claiming to be IT called asking for sensitive information?
Show us the results from your most recent technical impersonation simulation exercise.

items.text: How do your non-technical employees (admin staff, executives, HR) feel about verifying technical claims? Do they feel confident questioning someone who sounds technically knowledgeable?

scoring_guidance.green: Employees express comfort verifying technical claims, organizational culture celebrates appropriate skepticism, examples of employees who questioned technical authorities with positive outcomes
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed comfort levels, some employees hesitant to question technical expertise, concerns about appearing incompetent
scoring_guidance.red: Strong reluctance to question technical authorities, fear of appearing non-technical, 'imposter syndrome' prevents verification

followups.text: Has anyone in your organization ever reported a suspicious technical support contact? What happened to them?
Are there explicit policies protecting employees who insist on verification even when technical authorities pressure for immediate compliance?

solutions.title: Technical Authority Verification Protocol
solutions.description: Implement mandatory callback verification system for all unsolicited technical support contacts
solutions.implementation: Deploy callback verification requiring employees to call claimed organization's main number and request transfer to specific person. Create laminated reference cards with verification steps for all employee workstations. Include verified contact database accessible via company intranet.
solutions.technical_controls: Verified vendor contact database, callback procedure automation, helpdesk ticketing system integration, verification checklist pop-ups

solutions.title: Technical Request Authorization Workflow
solutions.description: Deploy digital approval system requiring supervisor and IT security approval for external technical support requests
solutions.implementation: Implement automated approval workflow with mandatory 24-hour delay for non-emergency technical access requests. Include multi-party authorization, automated notifications, approval tracking, and audit trail. Exception process requires CISO approval.
solutions.technical_controls: Workflow automation platform, approval tracking database, automated notifications, audit logging

solutions.title: Centralized Technical Support Log
solutions.description: Establish single point of contact that logs all external technical support interactions
solutions.implementation: Create IT helpdesk or security team as mandatory reporting point for all unsolicited technical contacts. Require immediate reporting with central team performing verification and response coordination. Weekly audit of logs to identify patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Central logging system, real-time alerting, pattern analysis tools, weekly audit reports

solutions.title: Technical Impersonation Simulation Training
solutions.description: Conduct quarterly simulated technical support calls and emails targeting different employee groups
solutions.implementation: Deploy phishing simulation platform with technical authority scenarios. Track compliance with verification protocols and provide immediate feedback. Focus on pressure tactics, urgency claims, and technical jargon. Measure improvement over time.
solutions.technical_controls: Phishing simulation platform, tracking dashboard, automated feedback system, competency assessments

solutions.title: Vendor Authentication Database
solutions.description: Create secure, searchable database of legitimate technical vendors and authorized personnel
solutions.implementation: Build and maintain database including legitimate vendor names, support contact numbers, authorized personnel with photos, and verification questions only real support would know. Make accessible to all employees through company intranet with mobile access.
solutions.technical_controls: Secure database system, intranet integration, mobile app, regular update workflow

solutions.title: Technical Request Documentation Standard
solutions.description: Require written documentation for all technical support interactions
solutions.implementation: Mandate documentation via email or ticket system for all technical support interactions including verification steps taken, approvals received, and actions performed. Implement monthly audit of technical support logs to identify patterns and improve procedures.
solutions.technical_controls: Ticketing system, documentation templates, automated compliance checking, monthly audit reports

solutions.title: Non-Technical Employee Empowerment Program
solutions.description: Develop programs specifically for non-technical staff to confidently verify technical claims
solutions.implementation: Create simple verification scripts that feel professional rather than questioning competence. Provide decision trees that don't require technical knowledge. Establish organizational culture celebrating appropriate technical verification. Train on recognizing pressure tactics.
solutions.technical_controls: Verification script cards, decision tree tools, employee recognition system, cultural communication campaign

risk_scenarios.title: Fake IT Support Credential Harvesting
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker calls employees claiming to be IT support needing to verify passwords for system update. Without verification protocols, employees provide credentials giving attackers immediate network access and lateral movement capability.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Phone call or email impersonating internal IT support with technical terminology and apparent system knowledge
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Cognitive offloading to technical authority combined with helpfulness compliance and imposter syndrome preventing questioning
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Kevin Mitnick campaigns - Extensively used technical support impersonation to harvest credentials across multiple organizations

risk_scenarios.title: Malicious Software Installation
risk_scenarios.description: Scammer poses as software vendor offering urgent security patch via email or phone. Employees with technical deference install malware disguised as legitimate software, creating persistent backdoors and data exfiltration capabilities.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Email with technical-sounding software update or phone call claiming critical patch needed
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Fear of security consequences combined with technical authority trust and complexity overwhelm
risk_scenarios.historical_example: RSA SecurID Breach 2011 - Spear-phishing with technical attachments appearing as legitimate system documentation exploited technical authority deference

risk_scenarios.title: Help Desk Social Engineering
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker calls internal help desk claiming to be employee who forgot password and needs urgent system access for client deadline. Help desk staff, wanting to provide good service, reset credentials without proper identity verification.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Internal help desk contact with technical problem claims and apparent knowledge of systems
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Service orientation combined with technical problem pressure and time constraints
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target Breach 2013 - Compromised vendor credentials likely obtained through help desk social engineering with technical authority claims

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Impersonation Data Theft
risk_scenarios.description: Fraudster contacts organization claiming to be from known technology vendor conducting security audit or compliance check. Employees provide sensitive system information, network diagrams, or database access enabling sophisticated targeted attacks.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Email or call claiming vendor audit/compliance requirements with technical terminology
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Compliance anxiety combined with technical authority deference and fear of regulatory consequences
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Anthem Breach 2015 - Social engineering included technical authority impersonation to gather system architecture information
